case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. M/s Shah Mohandas Sadhuram

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 144-145 of 1964 are before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTIONCivil Appeals Nos. 144-145 of 1964. Appeals from the order dated November

facts.text: Appeals are from the order dated November 16, 1960 of the Mysore High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 3/1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the order dated November 16, 1960 of the Mysore High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 3/1959. D. Karkhanis and R.N. Sachthey, for the appellant  in both the appeals . Ganapathy lyer, for the respondent  in both the appeals .

facts.text: Appeals are pursuant to a certificate granted by the High Court of Mysore under s. 66A of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals pursuant to a certificate granted by the High Court of Mysore under s. 66-A 2  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, are directed against its judgment answering the question referred to it in favour of the respondent-assessee.

facts.text: The assessee is M s Shah Mohandas Sadhuram, a firm.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, M s Shah Mohandas Sadhuram, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, is a firm.

facts.text: Assessee claimed registration under s. 26-A on Partnership Deed executed on April 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee claimed registration under s. 26-A of the Indian Income- Tax Act on the strength of a Partnership Deed executed on April 1, 1952.

facts.text: Four members were till 31-3-1952 members of a Joint Family and became divided on 31-3-1952 in status and by metes and bounds, each taking one fourth of joint family assets and liabilities.

anchor.surface_text: Whereof the above four members were till this day members of a Joint Family, whereof yesterday that is on 31-3-1952 the said four members have become divided number only in interest but also by metes and bounds, each of the said members taking to his share one fourth  1/4  of the said joint family assets and liabilities as detailed in the books of account as maintained by the firm known as Seth Mohandas Sadhuram

facts.text: First and second members (Atmaram and Doulatram, majors) decided to constitute partnership admitting third and fourth members (minors) to benefits but not to liabilities.

anchor.surface_text: and whereof we the first and second members have decided to companystitute all the said four members as a partnership admitting the third and fourth members thereof to the benefits of the said partnership but number to the liabilities thereunder.

facts.text: Firm to do business of Banking and Commerce, including Automobiles business under Vijaya Automobiles, Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: The said firm is agreed to do business of Banking and Commerce  which term includes all that is usually and customarily is understood to be done thereunder  and also to deal in Automobiles business. The Automobiles business having been started by the said first and second members under the name and style of Vijaya Automobiles, Mysore

facts.text: Capital contribution of each member equal, shown in personal capital ledger.

anchor.surface_text: It is agreed that the capital companytribution of each member will be equal and the accounts to be maintained to. indicate the said capital companytribution. will show what each member has so companytributed in the personal capital ledger account.

facts.text: Profits distributed pro rata capital after reserving six pies per rupee for Charity, losses shared likewise.

anchor.surface_text: It is further agreed that after debiting all working expenses inclusive of those referred to in para 6 supra. the profits of the firm less six pies per every rupee of profits which will be reserved for Charity Fund will be distributed pro rata according to the proportion of capital investment as detailed of each member.

facts.text: Share of profits for 3rd and 4th members (minors) paid to them, credited to their accounts, guardian draws maintenance etc.

anchor.surface_text: The share of profits for the 3rd and 4th member will be. paid to them. the said profits to be credited to theft accounts, and from there their maintenance charges and other expenses of necessities if any may be drawn by the said Guardian from the said accounts.

facts.text: Partnership duration one year from 1st April 1952 to 31st March 1953, may continue thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: It is agreed that the duration of this partnership will be for a period of one year, i.e. from 1st of April, 1952 to 31st March, 1953, and the members might agree to companytinue the said partnership even thereafter under these terms or on terms to be determined then.

facts.text: For assessment year 1953-54, ITO rejected registration because minors made parties to contract by eldest brother, minor debited with loss.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1953-54. the Income Tax Officer rejected the application for registration on the ground that in the case of the assessee. the minors are made parties to a companytract by the eldest brother acting on their behalf. The minor has actually been debited with a share of loss.

facts.text: For 1954-55, ITO rejected also on ground of supplementary deed dated 1-4-1953 extending life, on 10 annas stamp paper.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1954-55, he also rejected the application but added this further ground that a supplementary deed of partnership extending the life of the partnership beyond 1-4-1953 for a further period at the will of the partners is filed. This is on 10 annas stamp paper.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld ITO orders for both years.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner, on appeal, upheld the orders of the Income Tax Officer in respect of both the assessment years.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held assessee entitled to registration for both years, construing deed as admitting minors only to benefits.

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal, the Appellate Tribunal, following the decision of the Madras High Court in Jakka Devayya and Sons Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1  companystrued the deed as having admitted the minors only to the benefits of the partnership. It accordingly held that the assessee was entitled to be registered for both the years.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court at instance of Commissioner of Income Tax.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner of Income Tax, the Tribunal referred the question already set out above to the High Court.

facts.text: Mysore High Court answered question in favour of assessee, following its judgment in ITR No.2/1959.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, following its judgment in Income Tax Reference No. 2 of 1959, which is the subject- matter of appeal before us in The Commissioner of Income Tax Madras v. M s Shah Jethaji Phulchand 2  answered the question in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds partnership deed confers only benefits on minors, not full partners, entitled to registration.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the partnership deed, reasonably companystrued, only companyfers benefits of partnership on the two minors and does number make them full partners.

facts.text: Firm entitled to registration under s.26A for both years.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, agreeing with the High Court, we hold that the firm is entitled to be registered under s. 26-A of the Income Tax Act, and the answer to the question referred is in the affirmative.

facts.text: Supplementary deed dated April 1, 1953, nothing turns on its clauses.

anchor.surface_text: We may mention that the supplementary deed dated April 1, 1953, has number been included in the statement of the case, but it is companymon ground that numberhing turns on any of the clauses in the supplementary deed.

facts.text: Minor has actually been debited with a share of loss.

anchor.surface_text: The minor has actually been debited with a share of loss. Taking these facts into account.

facts.text: Joint family assets and liabilities detailed in books of firm Seth Mohandas Sadhuram.

anchor.surface_text: each of the said members taking to his share one fourth  1/4  of the said joint family assets and liabilities as detailed in the books of account as maintained by the firm known as Seth Mohandas Sadhuram

facts.text: Profits and losses of Bombay branch credited/debited separately.

anchor.surface_text: It is agreed that the profits and losses of the Bombay branch and other branches if any outside the State of Mysore will be credited or debited separately in the books of account of these branches
s. 66-A 2  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, are directed against its judgment answering the question referred to it in favour of the respondent-assessee.

issues.text: Whether the assessee, Mohandas Sadhuram, can be granted registration under Section 26-A of the Indian Income Tax Act on the basis of the partnership deed made on 1-4-1952 for the assessment year 1953-54 and on the basis of the said deed read with the supplementary deed on 1-4-1953 for the assessment year 1954-55.

precedents.citation: Jakka Devayya and Sons Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: Jakka Devayya and Sons Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1

precedents.case_name: Jakka Devayya and Sons v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: construed the deed as having admitted the minors only to the benefits of the partnership

precedents.citation: Income Tax Reference No. 2 of 1959, which is the subject- matter of appeal before us in The Commissioner of Income Tax Madras v. M s Shah Jethaji Phulchand 2

anchor.surface_text: Income Tax Reference No. 2 of 1959, which is the subject- matter of appeal before us in The Commissioner of Income Tax Madras v. M s Shah Jethaji Phulchand 2

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras v. Shah Jethaji Phulchand
precedents.cited_proposition: an instrument of partnership entered into between persons, some of whom are by law incompetent to contract, as might happen if one of them is a minor, is not necessarily null and void, and in a case like the present one, where the execution of the instrument of partnership on behalf of a minor by his guardian was for the purpose of admitting the minor to the benefits of partnership, no question of the invalidity of the instrument can properly arise

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay v. Dwarkadas Khetan Co. 3

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay v. Dwarkadas Khetan Co. 3

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay v. Dwarkadas Khetan Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: the income tax officer was only empowered to register a partnership which was specified in the instrument of partnership and it was not open to the Department to register a partnership different from that which was formed by the instrument; s. 30 of the Indian Partnership Act was designed to confer equal benefits upon the minor by treating him as a partner, but it did not render a minor competent and full partner, and any document which made a minor full partner could not be regarded as valid for the purpose of registration
precedents.cited_holding: in short, no distinction was made between the adult partner and the minor and to all intents and purposes, the minor was a full partner, even though under the partnership law he could only be admitted to the benefits of the partnership and not as a partner
